rule.description: ATT&CK: Powerview Add-DomainObjectAcl DCSync AD Extend Right

rule.description: ATT&CK T1050: APT29 Google Update Service Install
rule.info: This method detects malicious services mentioned in APT29 report by FireEye. ATT&CK T1054: Disabling Windows Event Auditing
rule.info: Detects scenarios where system auditing (ie: windows event log auditing) is disabled. This may be used in a scenario where an entity would want to bypass local logging to evade detection when windows event logging is enabled and reviewed. Also, it is recommended to turn off "Local Group Policy Object Processing" via GPO, which will make sure that Active Directory GPOs take precedence over local/edited computer policies via something such as "gpedit.msc". Please note, that disabling "Local Group Policy Object Processing" may cause an issue in scenarios of one off specific GPO modifications -- however it is recommended to perform these modifications in Active Directory anyways.

rule.info: The 'LsaRegisterLogonProcess' function verifies that the application making the function call is a logon process by checking that it has the SeTcbPrivilege privilege set. Possible Rubeus tries to get a handle to LSA.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1136: Local User Creation
rule.info: Detects local user creation on windows servers, which shouldn't happen in an Active Directory environment. Apply this Sigma Use Case on your windows server logs and not on your DC logs.
Falsepositives: Domain Controller Logs. Local accounts managed by privileged account management tools.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1089: Suspicious Driver Loaded By User
rule.info: Detects the loading of drivers via 'SeLoadDriverPrivilege' required to load or unload a device driver. With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode. This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers. If you exclude privileged users/admins and processes, which are allowed to do so, you are maybe left with bad programs trying to load malicious kernel drivers. This will detect Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs) and the usage of Sysinternals and various other tools. So you have to work with a whitelist to find the bad stuff.

Falsepositives: {'Other legimate tools loading drivers. There are some': 'Sysinternals, CPU-Z, AVs etc. - but not much. You have to baseline this according to your used products and allowed tools. Also try to exclude users, which are allowed to load drivers.'}.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1004: Winlogon Helper DLL
rule.info: Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete. Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1042: Change Default File Association
rule.info: When a file is opened, the default program used to open the file (also called the file association or handler) is checked. File association selections are stored in the Windows Registry and can be edited by users, administrators, or programs that have Registry access or by administrators using the built-in assoc utility. Applications can modify the file association for a given file extension to call an arbitrary program when a file with the given extension is opened.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1040: Network Sniffing
rule.info: Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless connection. An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1055: Suspicious In-Memory Module Execution
rule.info: Detects the access to processes by other suspicious processes which have reflectively loaded libraries in their memory space. An example is SilentTrinity C2 behaviour. Generally speaking, when Sysmon EventID 10 cannot reference a stack call to a dll loaded from disk (the standard way), it will display "UNKNOWN" as the module name. Usually this means the stack call points to a module that was reflectively loaded in memory. Adding to this, it is not common to see such few calls in the stack (ntdll.dll --> kernelbase.dll --> unknown) which essentially means that most of the functions required by the process to execute certain routines are already present in memory, not requiring any calls to external libraries. The latter should also be considered suspicious.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1055: Suspicious In-Memory Module Execution
rule.info: Detects the access to processes by other suspicious processes which have reflectively loaded libraries in their memory space. An example is SilentTrinity C2 behaviour. Generally speaking, when Sysmon EventID 10 cannot reference a stack call to a dll loaded from disk (the standard way), it will display "UNKNOWN" as the module name. Usually this means the stack call points to a module that was reflectively loaded in memory. Adding to this, it is not common to see such few calls in the stack (ntdll.dll --> kernelbase.dll --> unknown) which essentially means that most of the functions required by the process to execute certain routines are already present in memory, not requiring any calls to external libraries. The latter should also be considered suspicious.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1003: Dumping Lsass.exe Memory with MiniDumpWriteDump API
rule.info: Detects the use of MiniDumpWriteDump API for dumping lsass.exe memory in a stealth way. Tools like ProcessHacker and some attacker tradecract use this API found in dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll. As an example, SilentTrynity C2 Framework has a module that leverages this API to dump the contents of Lsass.exe and transfer it over the network back to the attacker's machine.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1003: Load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL from Suspicious Process
rule.info: Detects the load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL (used to make memory dumps) by suspicious processes. Tools like ProcessHacker and some attacker tradecract use MiniDumpWriteDump API found in dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll. As an example, SilentTrynity C2 Framework has a module that leverages this API to dump the contents of Lsass.exe and transfer it over the network back to the attacker's machine.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1003: Load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL from Suspicious Process
rule.info: Detects the load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL (used to make memory dumps) by suspicious processes. Tools like ProcessHacker and some attacker tradecract use MiniDumpWriteDump API found in dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll. As an example, SilentTrynity C2 Framework has a module that leverages this API to dump the contents of Lsass.exe and transfer it over the network back to the attacker's machine.

rule.description: ATT&CK: Suspicious Keyboard Layout Load
rule.info: Detects the keyboard preload installation with a suspicious keyboard layout, e.g. Chinese, Iranian or Vietnamese layout load in user session on systems maintained by US staff only
Falsepositives: Administrators or users that actually use the selected keyboard layouts (heavily depends on the organisation's user base).

rule.description: ATT&CK T1208: Suspicious Outbound Kerberos Connection
rule.info: Detects suspicious outbound network activity via kerberos default port indicating possible lateral movement or first stage PrivEsc via delegation.

rule.description: Whitelist Interaction: Suspicious Outbound Kerberos Connection
ATT&CK T1055: Suspicious Remote Thread Created
rule.info: Offensive tradecraft is switching away from using APIs like "CreateRemoteThread", however, this is still largely observed in the wild. This rule aims to detect suspicious processes (those we would not expect to behave in this way like word.exe or outlook.exe) creating remote threads on other processes. It is a generalistic rule, but it should have a low FP ratio due to the selected range of processes.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1041: Suspicious ADSI-Cache Usage By Unknown Tool
rule.info: detects the usage of ADSI (LDAP) operations by tools. This may also detect tools like LDAPFragger.
Falsepositives: Other legimate tools, which do ADSI (LDAP) operations, e.g. any remoting activity by MMC, Powershell, Windows etc..

rule.description: Whitelist Interaction: Suspicious ADSI-Cache Usage By Unknown Tool
ATT&CK T1023: Suspicious desktop.ini Action
rule.info: Detects unusual processes accessing desktop.ini, which can be leveraged to alter how Explorer displays a folder's content (i.e. renaming files) without changing them on disk.
Falsepositives: Operations performed through Windows SCCM or equivalent.

rule.description: Whitelist Interaction: Suspicious desktop.ini Action
ATT&CK T1060: Suspicious RUN Key from Download
rule.info: Detects the suspicious RUN keys created by software located in Download or temporary Outlook/Internet Explorer directories
Falsepositives: Software installers downloaded and used by users.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1050: Suspicious Driver Load from Temp
rule.info: Detects a driver load from a temporary directory
Falsepositives: there is a relevant set of false positives depending on applications in the environment.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1073: Possible Process Hollowing Image Loading
rule.info: Detects Loading of samlib.dll, WinSCard.dll from untypical process e.g. through process hollowing by Mimikatz
Falsepositives: Very likely, needs more tuning.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1177: DLL Load via LSASS
rule.info: Detects a method to load DLL via LSASS process using an undocumented Registry key

rule.description: ATT&CK T1193: dotNET DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rule.info: Detects any assembly DLL being loaded by an Office Product
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1193: CLR DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rule.info: Detects CLR DLL being loaded by an Office Product
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1193: GAC DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rule.info: Detects any GAC DLL being loaded by an Office Product
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1193: Active Directory Parsing DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rule.info: Detects DSParse DLL being loaded by an Office Product
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1193: Active Directory Kerberos DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rule.info: Detects Kerberos DLL being loaded by an Office Product
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1085 T1086: PowerShell Rundll32 Remote Thread Creation
rule.info: Detects PowerShell remote thread creation in Rundll32.exe

rule.description: ATT&CK T1089: Suspicious PROCEXP152.sys File Created In TMP
rule.info: Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder. This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.

Falsepositives: Other legimate tools using this driver and filename (like Sysinternals). Note - Clever attackers may easily bypass this detection by just renaming the driver filename. Therefore just Medium-level and don't rely on it..

rule.description: ATT&CK: Suspicious Program Location with Network Connections
rule.info: Detects programs with network connections running in suspicious files system locations

rule.description: ATT&CK T1210: Suspicious Outbound RDP Connections
rule.info: Detects Non-Standard Tools Connecting to TCP port 3389 indicating possible lateral movement
Falsepositives: Other Remote Desktop RDP tools.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1060: Registry Persistence via Explorer Run Key
rule.info: Detects a possible persistence mechanism using RUN key for Windows Explorer and pointing to a suspicious folder

rule.description: ATT&CK T1060: New RUN Key Pointing to Suspicious Folder
rule.info: Detects suspicious new RUN key element pointing to an executable in a suspicious folder
Falsepositives: Software using weird folders for updates.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1089: Suspicious Service Installed
rule.info: Detects installation of NalDrv or PROCEXP152 services via registry-keys to non-system32 folders. Both services are used in the tool Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU)

Falsepositives: Other legimate tools using this service names and drivers. Note - clever attackers may easily bypass this detection by just renaming the services. Therefore just Medium-level and don't rely on it..

rule.description: Whitelist Interaction: Suspicious Service Installed
Whitelist Interaction: Suspicious Service Installed
ATT&CK T1193: VBA DLL Loaded Via Microsoft Word
rule.info: Detects DLL's Loaded Via Word Containing VBA Macros
Falsepositives: Alerts on legitimate macro usage as well, will need to filter as appropriate.

rule.description: ATT&CK T1047: Windows Mangement Instrumentation DLL Loaded Via Microsoft Word
rule.info: Detects DLL's Loaded Via Word Containing VBA Macros Executing WMI Commands

rule.description: ATT&CK T1073 T1038 T1112: Svchost DLL Search Order Hijack
rule.info: IKEEXT and SessionEnv service, as they call LoadLibrary on files that do not exist within C:\Windows\System32\ by default. An attacker can place their malicious logic within the PROCESS_ATTACH block of their library and restart the aforementioned services "svchost.exe -k netsvcs" to gain code execution on a remote machine.

rule.description: Whitelist Interaction: Svchost DLL Search Order Hijack
ATT&CK: Usage of Sysinternals Tools
rule.info: Detects the usage of Sysinternals Tools due to accepteula key being added to Registry
Falsepositives: Legitimate use of SysInternals tools. Programs that use the same Registry Key.

rule.description: ATT&CK: Hijack Legit RDP Session to Move Laterally
rule.info: Detects the usage of tsclient share to place a backdoor on the RDP source machine's startup folder

rule.description: ATT&CK T1088: UAC Bypass via Event Viewer
rule.info: Detects UAC bypass method using Windows event viewer
